summary.text_en: In his book 'Discourses and Mathematical Demonstrations Relating to Two New Sciences', Galileo laid the foundation for modern kinematics and strength of materials. Through experiment and mathematics, he described the law of falling bodies (distance proportional to time squared) and the principle of inertia.
key_points_en: Principle of Inertia (basis for Newton's 1st Law)
Projectile motion is a combination of horizontal and vertical motion

story.text_en: The story of Galileo dropping two balls of different masses from the Leaning Tower of Pisa to disprove Aristotle (who said heavier objects fall faster) is likely a myth. Galileo's true genius was his inclined plane experiment: by rolling balls down a ramp, he cleverly 'slowed down' gravity enough to measure the time with crude tools (like his own pulse or a water clock). He discovered that the distance fallen is proportional to the *square* of the time taken, and deduced that all objects, regardless of mass, fall at the same rate in a vacuum.

fun_facts.text_en: This book was published in Leiden, Netherlands, because Galileo was under house arrest by the Roman Inquisition in Florence for his support of Copernican heliocentrism. His works were banned in Italy.
Like his earlier astronomical work, this book is written as a dialogue between three characters: Salviati, Sagredo, and Simplicio.

simple_explanation.text_en: On the Moon (where there is no air), Apollo 15 astronaut David Scott dropped a hammer and a feather at the same time. They hit the ground *simultaneously*. This perfectly proved Galileo's 400-year-old theory: gravity pulls all objects the same way, and lighter objects don't fall slower.

applications.text_en: The 'second new science' in the book was about the strength of materials, analyzing why beams and rods break, which is the beginning of modern civil and mechanical engineering.

impact.text_en: This book is considered the foundation of modern physics. Galileo created the 'scientific method' by describing motion in the language of mathematics and insisting that experiment was the only arbiter of truth. Einstein called him 'the father of modern science'.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Aristotelian physics (as the primary theory to be disproven)
Archimedes (as the model for using mathematics to describe the physical world)
Copernicus (Galileo's law of inertia was necessary to provide a physical defense for a moving-Earth, heliocentric model)

influenced.contribution_en: Provided the conceptual and experimental basis for Newton's First Law (Inertia) and Second Law (acceleration)
His measurement of a constant $g$ (gravitational acceleration) is the direct manifestation of Newton's law of gravity at the Earth's surface

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Galileo replaced Aristotle's philosophical, 'purpose-based' speculation with experiments and mathematics, separating physics from philosophy and turning it into an empirical science.

quiz.question_en: What key mathematical relationship between distance (d) and time (t) did Galileo's famous inclined plane experiment reveal?
options_en: Distance is proportional to time ($d \propto t$)
Distance is proportional to the square of time ($d \propto t^2$)
Distance is inversely proportional to time ($d \propto 1/t$)
quiz.explanation_en: This was Galileo's great discovery. Constant velocity is $d \propto t$, but he proved that constant acceleration (from gravity) follows $d \propto t^2$. For example, if it falls 1 meter in 1 second, it will fall 4 meters in 2 seconds and 9 meters in 3 seconds.
